Award.AwardTitle: Design of New Ruthenium Catalysts for Olefin Insertion Polymerization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Zhibin Guan of the University of California-Irvine is supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program in the Division of Chemistry to explore the scope of a new family of Ru (II) complexes which his lab recently discovered and showed that they have catalytic activity towards olefin insertion polymerization and copolymerization of alpha-olefins with polar monomers. Plans are presented to achieve higher activities through catalyst tuning based on the design of various new ligand architectures, and on a better understanding of the catalytic system and the reaction mechanism. Computational modeling will be conducted to complement the experimental mechanistic and activity studies. The polymerization activities of the complexes will be correlated with the structures of the catalysts. The trends observed and the insights gained will guide further design of better Ru-based olefin polymerization catalysts.

The copolymerization of olefins with polar monomers continues to be a significant challenge and the proposed research has the potential to lead to better routes to functionalized polyolefins and consequently to new polymeric materials with important specialized applications. The proposed research will provide students and postdoctoral researchers with valuable educational experience in organometallic chemistry, polymerization, catalysis, kinetics, and computational science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary of Outcome:

Polyolefin industry produces millions of tons of important polymeric materials ranging from plastics, fibers, to elastomers. The search for better polymerization catalysts is an important research area because discovery of more efficient catalysts will enable us to produce better products at reduced cost, less energy consumption and environmental pollution. The objective of this study is to design and investigate new ruthenium-based catalysts for olefin insertion polymerization. We seek to design and discover Ru-based catalysts that can potentially combine high reactivity for olefin polymerization while maintaining good functional group tolerance. Toward this goal, we have made significant progress for this project in the following three areas: (A) Developed a series of Ru(II) complexes with piano stool geometry that are active for ethylene polymerization, and unambiguously demonstrated for the first time ethylene insertion on a cationic Ru center; (B) Developed the first series of Ru(IV) complexes with disulfonatophosphine (OPO) ligands that are active for ethylene polymerization; and (C) Developed Cp*Ru(IV)-dithiocarbonate complexes for ethylene polymerization.

Intellectual Merit:

This research project features both fundamental and applied intellectual merits. Fundamental merit includes the design and discovery of a completely new family of Ru(II)-based complexes as active catalysts for olefin insertion. Our successful development of new Ru(II)-based catalysts opens a new avenue in olefin polymerization catalysis. The novel concepts for designing unique ligands and Ru(II) complexes is also  of fundamental interests to organometallic community. For applications, discovery of efficient and viable transition metal catalysts for olefin polymerization should have applications in polyolefin industry.

Broader Impacts:

The basic information generated from this study should benefit the general research community and the broader polyolefin industry. For education and student training, this multi-disciplinary research activity has provided excellent training for both undergraduate and graduate students in many areas including organic synthesis, organometallic, and polymer synthesis and polymer property studies. This has provided great opportunities to train graduate and undergraduate students, especially for minority and women students currently working on this project. During this research period, the PI has also strongly committed to various outreach programs that are aimed to excite the younger generation with science and to enhance general public understanding and appreciation of chemical sciences and technologies.

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2014
Modified by: Zhibin Guan
